Comment: Without a speaker the House of Representatives cannot function. When the newly elected house first convenes the clerk of the House will call the members to order. One by one the clerk will call on each member to vote by surname for the speaker. If no person receives the majority the whole process starts all over again. If no one is chosen the process will repeat itself, sometimes for weeks.  The most extreme case comes from [1855](https://history.house.gov/Historical-Highlights/1851-1900/The-longest-and-most-contentious-Speaker-election-in-its-history/) when 21 different candidates ran for the speakership. In that year the House was able to choose a speaker after 133 rounds of voting over the course of 2 months.

Comment: You're right, the process I described above is not in the Constitution. According to my old copy of the *House Rules and Manual* the speaker was originally elected by paper ballots. The current method of members voting by voice during a roll call started in 1839. The procedure is also codified in the *House Rules* which state in Rule II 2(a):  >At the commencement of the first session of each Congress, the Clerk shall call the Members, Delegates, and Resident Commissioner to order and proceed to record their presence by States in alphabetical order, either by call of the roll or by use of the electronic voting system. **Pending the election of a Speaker or Speaker pro tempore, and in the absence of a Member acting as Speaker pro tempore pursuant to clause 8(b)(3)(A) of rule I, the Clerk shall preserve order and decorum and decide all questions of order, subject to appeal by a Member, Delegate, or Resident Commissioner**.
